awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Printing Dynamics during Inkjetting of Cell-Laden Bioink for 3D Biomanufacturing Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Inkjet printing, where droplets of liquid are deposited onto a substrate in a computer-controlled pattern, is one of the most promising technologies for creation of 3D living tissues and organs. The adopted carrier fluid, referred to as bioink, incorporates living cells. Due to cell-cell interaction, living cells adhere to each other in the print nozzle to form cell aggregates. These aggregates can clog the nozzle or result in unplanned droplets deposited on the substrate, both of which can significantly affect inkjet printing reliability. This project involves fundamental scientific research to understand the mechanisms of living cell adhesion and aggregation during inkjet printing, and how to control the printing outcomes.   If successful, this research can bridge jet-based bioprinting manufacturing science and biomedical applications, open new avenues in regeneration of 3D functional tissues and organs, and significantly advance the U.S. healthcare industry. The research outcomes will be seamlessly integrated into a biomanufacturing course currently offered in the Manufacturing Engineering and Bioengineering programs to increase participation of female and minority students. The research will also be disseminated through the regional summer camp (Explore Engineering) and national mass media to educate and inspire the general public and the next generation of bioengineers. Engagement of graduate students in the research activities will strengthen the future workforce in bioengineering and advanced manufacturing industries.

The research objective is to gain fundamental new knowledge regarding cell aggregation inside the printhead nozzle, and the satellite droplet formation outside the nozzle during inkjet printing of cell-laden bioink. During printing, the bioink is ejected from a piezoelectric printhead to form droplets, which are precisely deposited on the substrate to form 3D constructs layer by layer. It is believed that the nature of pressure wave required to expel the bioink from the nozzle affects both the likelihood of cell aggregation and satellite drop formation.  To investigate cell aggregation, cell adhesion will be simulated using a multiphase approach, which models the bioink as a suspension coupling a viscoelastic fluid model with a solid model for living cells. The governing equations for the conservation of mass and momentum will be numerically solved under different excitation voltages and cell concentrations. As the satellite droplet formation depends on the competing actions of ligament radial thinning and axial contraction, both processes will be modeled analytically to predict satellite droplet formation. Once the core fundamentals are understood, the knowledge will be leveraged to generate process phase diagrams in terms of non-dimensional numbers to ultimately identify optimal printing conditions. Additionally, cell viability and proliferation will be assessed immediately after printing and after 7-day incubation to confirm the chosen inkjet printing conditions have no negative impact on the cells. The resulting scientific knowledge is highly adoptable to other biofabrication technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Inkjet printing as a type of 3D printing technique has been widely used to fabricate 3D tissue/organ models for a variety of 3D bioprinting applications, such as tissue/organ regeneration and drug screening/delivery. The bioink used in 3D bioprinting is a suspension composed of biomaterials and living cells. During the printing process, living cells suspended in the bioink sediment and adhere to each other to form cell aggregates through cell-cell interaction. The cell aggregation has been widely recognized as a critical challenge in 3D bioprinting, because it makes the printing process extremely unstable resulting in poor printing quality, and the large cell aggregates could even block the nozzle. Therefore, it is very important to understand the fundamental knowledge regarding 1) why the living cells aggregate? 2) How to quantify the cell aggregation? and 3) is there a way to mitigate the cell aggregation in order to improve the printing performance? These questions are investigated and answered by the outcomes in this project.

 

In this research, the PI has key outcomes as follows: 1) Mechanism of cell aggregation within bioink reservoir. We have found the main reason for cell aggregation to be cell sedimentation. We have further studied the physics of cell sedimentation and aggregation by analyzing the major forces including drag force, buoyant force, cell adhesion force, and gravitational force. We found that the individual cell sedimentation velocity is nearly constant due to a balance of the drag force, buoyant force, and gravitational force. The cell adhesion force due to cell-cell interaction is negligible when the distance between cells is greater than 20 µm. 2) Cell aggregates within the nozzle. We found from experiments that the cells within the nozzle prefer the centerline area due to the smaller shear force. More cells accumulate in this area facilitate cell aggregation. In addition, we have performed the simulation and found that the cells close to bioink meniscus could be reflected to the centerline area due to meniscus oscillation which further enhances the cell aggregation. 3) Effects of cell aggregation on output cell number within microspheres and cell printing efficiency. We have developed a numerical modeling framework by coupling the cell sedimentation and the bioink consumption to precisely predict output cell number within microspheres with the printing time. The model also predicts cell printing efficiency and identifies optimal inkjet frequency range. The model has been validated by experimental results. 4) Active circulation to mitigate cell sedimentation and aggregation. A peristaltic pump equipped with a 10-roller rotor extracts the bioink from the bottom of bioink reservoir and replenishes it to the top to achieve active circulation of the bioink within the reservoir. The proposed active circulation approach is an effective and efficient approach with superior performance in mitigating cell sedimentation and aggregation, and the resulting knowledge is easily applicable to other 3D bioprinting techniques significantly improving printing reliability and quality in 3D bioprinting.

 

This research contributes to the physical understanding of cell adhesion and aggregation mechanism and the effect of cell aggregation on output cell number encapsulated within microspheres during inkjet printing of cell-laden bioink. The resulting knowledge of this project significantly improves the process reliability and printing quality, promoting inkjet printing as a viable technology for a variety of 3D bioprinting applications. The physical understanding gained from the proposed research is highly adoptable to other 3D bioprinting techniques, such as laser-assisted printing, microextrusion, to name a few. Moreover, the resulting research accomplishments accelerate biomedical research and possible commercial applications in tissue/organ printing and regenerative medicine, improving the quality of a healthy life for everyone.

 


Last Modified: 12/10/2023
Modified by: Changxue Xu
